The Department of Agriculture has approved free meals for all children under 18 years of age until December 31st. However, the program can change at any time due to lack of funding with the Department of Agriculture. It is very important for all households to still return their Free/Reduce meal application because it determines your status for the entire year.
When the program for free meals ends, we will have to charge for lunch depending on your child's meal status. We will continue to accept meal applications throughout the school year.
Pick up locations are located at Door 13 at Salmon Campus and the Visitors Entrance at the St. Regis Mohawk School. Meals can be picked up from 11:00-1:00 each day.

August 14 at 11:54 AM ·

Good Morning,
I am asking all students going into seventh and eighth grade to check their Chromebooks and chargers to make sure they are running and set for September. If you are having issues with your Chromebook or charger, please call our office at 518-358-6650. We will help you out. All students will need their Chromebooks and chargers for the first day of school.

Sixth-grade students will receive new Chromebooks and chargers during Orientation on August 28th.

Any student who is transferring out of the district will need to turn in their Chromebook, case, and charger to avoid being charged for these items.

Any student going into 9th grade will need to turn in their Chromebook, case, and charger from the middle school. You will receive a new one in High School.

If you have any questions please call our office.
Thank you.
Stay safe, stay healthy.
Tammy Russell
Middle School Principal

District election ballots have been mailed to District residents. Anyone needing additional ballots for “qualified” voters in their household should contact Kim Treptow at 518-358-6614 or email ktreptow@srk12.org.

A self-addressed stamped envelope as well as a voter attestation have been included with the ballot. The attestation certifies that you are a qualified voter of the District. All ballots and attestations must be received by mail or in the locked box at Door 3 of the Salmon River Elementary by 5pm on June 9th. Ballots received after this time will not be counted.

A “qualified” voter is defined under the law as:

A citizen of the United States
Eighteen years of age or older
A resident within the district for a period of thirty days preceding the meeting or election at which they offer to vote
No person shall have the right to register for or vote at any school meeting or election who would not be qualified to register for or vote at an election in accordance with the provisions of Section 5-106 of the election law

Dear Parents and Guardians,

In light of our voluntary school closing, we want to ensure that all families will still have access to school meals. We will be providing prepared meals through our Food Service Department at no cost to students. Meals will be available to all children 18 and under residing within our district. We will provide both breakfast and lunch at pickup points from 10:00- 11:30 am starting Tuesday March 17, until our schools reopen.

Meals will be available at the following sites for pickup: Rainbow Park Fort Covington, Generations Park Hogansburg and Elm Circle parking lot in Westville. Parents can pick up meals for their children, children will not be required to be present.

Our hope is that this will help with the pressure these unprecedented times are placing on our families and community.

If you have any questions about the program please feel free to contact Nicole Foster at 518-358-6682 or nfoster@srk12.org.

Congratulations again to the team as it is truly a team effort to achieve this award and to the following individual scholar athletes: Joryan Adams, Myranda Collette, Delanie Deshane, Olivia Moulton, Lindsay Martin, Karli St. Ann, Kamea Thomas, and Talynn Wylie

post_text: National Mix It Up In Lunch Day - A national campaign launched by Teaching Tolerance over a decade ago, Mix It Up at Lunch encourages students to identify, question and cross social boundaries. Survey results, students have identified the cafeteria as the place where divisions are most clearly drawn. So on October 22nd, we asked students to move out of their comfort zones and connect with someone new over lunch. It’s a simple act with profound implications. Studies have shown that interactions across group lines can help reduce prejudice. When students interact with those who are different from them, biases and misperceptions can fall away. We had a puzzle at each table for students to collaborate to complete their puzzle. The table who completes the puzzle first will be awarded a free snack.

Welcome to Salmon River Central!
New teachers at Salmon River Central attended a 2-day orientation on August 21 & 22 led by Assistant Superintendent Angela Robert and the District Instructional Support Team. The two days were focused on acquainting the new staff with district expectations such as building strong relationships with students and their families, and the importance of data in planning and delivering instruction. The orientation also was aimed at helping them become familiar with the school and community culture -including a Mohawk Language lesson, district systems, and procedures, as well as best teaching strategies for students from all backgrounds. New staff enjoyed lunch with their building principals and attended special presentations by Chief Beverly Cook and Education Director Stephanie Cook, both from the St. Regis Mohawk Tribe. We are happy to welcome our newest staff to the Salmon River Central community.
